subject: Re: [junit] @Ignore with a time
msgSnippet: I think that would address my concern that @ignore can be forgotten. A failing test would be a really nice reminder: ignore expired:  I have
messageBody:
I think that would address my concern that @ignore can be forgotten.
A failing test would be a really nice reminder: "ignore expired: <your
message>"
I have not yet used ignore I have not seen the need, when do you typically
need it?

On 6/8/06, Brett L. Schuchert <schuchert@...> wrote:
>
> I've been working with a group for the past 3.5 years and we've been
> using JUnit from the beginning. A while back, as the project grew,
> there were times when we would break tests (or because we had
> external dependencies that we had to wait and had not yet mocked
> things out), tests would fail for a few days before we could get to
> them.
>
> This stopped our CI, so we introduced a helper class, TimeBomb. We'd
> add a call to TimeBomb with a date and the test would stop failing
> until after the provided date.
>
> It was an active way to remind us go back and fix something in a few
> days.
>
> @Ignore has a message. What about adding a date? Ignore until the
> date, after which the test will fail by throwing a runtime exception?
>
> Is that crazy?
>
> Brett
>
>
>
